content.raw:
Asynchronous updates are bad - the short high times on the pulseblaster are just to make them *consistently* bad. At the moment, if you use the below code, the delay after a rising edge might be 100 nanoseconds plus 100 microseconds plus jitter, or it might be several seconds plus 100 microseconds plus jitter, depending on the timing of the next instruction. We're just trying to make it *consistently* 100 nanoseconds plus 100 microseconds plus jitter, by making the pulseblaster's falling edges come 100 nanoseconds after the rising ones.

This is what the existing setup in the lab I'm in does, and we are trying to emulate that on one hand. On the other hand, the correct solution if one wants to make this better isn't to make labscript produce falling edges earlier — it's to use synchronous updating. That's what this lab will do eventually, if not use different DDS device altogether. This is just a stop-gap and a way to verify that the transition from one control system to the other is being done correctly.
